g.text: Taking it to the next level
we consistency, in this case it's more important
Also RDBMS allows you to query auctions in a related way
Tagging is easily done with RDBMS
Assuming reading is a lot more than write
If we assume 10M auctions a day, there are roughly 100K seconds a day,
If 1B bids a day, 10k bids per second
Placing bids is going to be a lot more than creating bids
Service will publish bid to db for persistence,
Publish bid to redis for real time comm,
can use redis to track winning bid,
if cache expires -> leads to cache miss and service must query from db
Offloads read traffic from main DB
Publishes bid updates to Redis for real-time updates.
Writes bid information to the primary database.
In this case, since WebSocket connection is between client and Orchestrator Service, this service needs to subscribe to redis
We can have two different databases, an auction data store and a bid data store.
Auction DB will store Auction along with registered users, auction status - open/close/cancelled, final price, auction expire time ( in local datetime ) and current highest bid.
We can also split BidService into two, one for BidPosting,
and another for BidReading, this allows us to scale them independently.
Consider redis cache, for highest bids
